text:
```abstract type Person end
mutable struct Physicist <: Person
   name::String
end
physicist = "Richard Feynman"
isa(physicist, Person) == true```

elements.text:
abstract type Person end
mutable struct Physicist <: Person
   name::String
end
physicist = "Richard Feynman"
isa(physicist, Person) == true

text: I'm guessing abstract types are more like traits in Rust? They tell you "hey, this struct defines this kind of behaviour", not "this struct extends this other struct"

elements.text: I'm guessing abstract types are more like traits in Rust? They tell you "hey, this struct defines this kind of behaviour", not "this struct extends this other struct"

text: It is used a great deal, e.g. to allow different sorts of Arrays to work with functions that are defined to take the shared abstraction rather than multiple functions one for each kind of array.

elements.text: It is used a great deal, e.g. to allow different sorts of Arrays to work with functions that are defined to take the shared abstraction rather than multiple functions one for each kind of array.

text: How

elements.text: How

text: To give you an example, Julia defines a base FFT (fast Fourier transform) interface but you can have many different implementations of it. The way you do FFT in Julia is the same, fft(), rfft(), etc. but you may have FFTW.jl, which binds to FFTW3 (FFT computed on the CPU) or CUDA.jl, which exposes CUFFT (FFT computed on the GPU)

elements.text: To give you an example, Julia defines a base FFT (fast Fourier transform) interface but you can have many different implementations of it. The way you do FFT in Julia is the same, fft(), rfft(), etc. but you may have FFTW.jl, which binds to FFTW3 (FFT computed on the CPU) or CUDA.jl, which exposes CUFFT (FFT computed on the GPU)

text:
An easier example is with floating point numbers.  There is an abstract type `AbstractFloat` , if I want to define a function that will work to halve values of type Float16 and Float32 and Float64, I can write
```half(x::Abstract Float) = x / 2```

elements.text: An easier example is with floating point numbers.  There is an abstract type
AbstractFloat
, if I want to define a function that will work to halve values of type Float16 and Float32 and Float64, I can write
half(x::Abstract Float) = x / 2

text:
```julia> half(x::AbstractFloat) = x / 2
half (generic function with 1 method)

julia> half(1.0f0)
0.5f0

julia> half(1.0)
0.5```

elements.text:
julia> half(x::AbstractFloat) = x / 2
half (generic function with 1 method)

julia> half(1.0f0)
0.5f0

julia> half(1.0)
0.5
